qas.question: What did South Africa's Constitution Declare to be?
What laws did they introduce to support blacks?
Who does the term "black" people include?
Who makes the "Coloured" people feel "Not black enough"?
Who is favored more under the affirmative action policies?

context: In the post-apartheid era, the Constitution of South Africa has declared the country to be <a0_0>a "Non-racial democracy"<a0_0/>. In an effort to redress past injustices, the ANC government has introduced laws in support of <a1_0>affirmative action policies<a1_0/> for Blacks; under these they define "Black" people to include <a2_0>"Africans", "Coloureds" and "Asians"<a2_0/>. Some affirmative action policies favor <a4_0>"Africans<a4_0/>" over "Coloureds" in terms of qualifying for certain benefits. Some South Africans categorized as "African Black" say that "Coloureds" did not suffer as much as they did during apartheid. "Coloured" South Africans are known to discuss their dilemma by saying, "we were not white enough under apartheid, and we are not black enough under the <a3_0>ANC (African National Congress)<a3_0/>".[citation needed]
